titleInfo.title: Tracing the Historical Increase of Sediment Organic Carbon in a Coastal Lagoon
titleInfo.subTitle: Insights from Dual Analytical Approaches

name.namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.abstract: This study investigated the spatiotemporal changes in sediment organic carbon (OC) content in Apalachicola Bay, Florida, USA employing two complementary analytical approaches. The first approach compared region-wide surface sediment samples collected from three time points in the past 60 years and the second approach analyzed dated sediment cores from the past century in key locations identified by the surface sample comparisons. Both approaches revealed a consistent increase in OC content since the 1950s.The most significant change was a regionwide significant increase in OC concentration from a median of 6.6 mg g-1 to 23.8 mg g-1 occurring between 1959 and 1994. Lignin degradation indices showed (Ad:Al)v oxidation levels from 0.21 to 0.36 and 3,5Bd/V indicating low to moderate degradation of soil OC. S/V of 0.82 to 0.98 indicated angiosperm dominance, while C/V ratios of 0.12 to 0.39 reflected varying woody and non-woody tissue proportions. Distance from the mainland and the river mouth trended with higher degradation and oxidation, lower lignin, and more non-woody OC sources when comparing seaward cores from those closer to the mainland. Core depth profiles revealed significant changes in oxidation, degradation, and lignin content by factors up to 2.4 in the past 5 decades. Comparison between the two approaches in this study revealed A) both approaches indicated a significant increase in OC content through time and B) that there was less agreement on the exact OC concentrations for older samples than the newer. Despite potential differences arising from dating, elemental analyses, or spatial sampling, both approaches underscore the onset of OC accumulation coinciding with historical anthropogenic activities, particularly the construction of dams and extensive dredging in the region. These findings shed light on the complex interactions between human activities, environmental stressors, and sediment OC dynamics in coastal ecosystems, emphasizing the importance of multi-approach analyses for comprehensive understanding and management of such systems.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Joshua L. Breithaupt, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Jeffrey P. Chanton, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Robert G. M. Spencer, Committee Member; Markus H. Huettel, Committee Member.
